awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Large-scale brain dynamics underlying visual perceptual awareness
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite the enormous progress in neuroscience over the past century, the neurobiological basis of our subjective awareness remains a mystery. Advances over the past decades have now enabled one major component of this question to be rigorously addressed by modern neuroscientific tools. That is, how does the brain give rise to perceptual awareness of sensory stimuli? In particular, there has been a concerted effort by neuroscientists and psychologists to unravel the neural bases of visual perceptual awareness. Currently, one major open question is whether regions in the human frontal cortex directly contribute to the content of visual perceptual awareness or, alternatively, are only involved in the maintenance and manipulation of perceptual information represented in posterior visual cortices. With the support of this NSF CAREER award, Dr. Biyu He will address this question and develop a framework for understanding large-scale brain dynamics underlying visual perceptual awareness. To this end, the project combines visual psychophysics, state-of-the-art multimodal human brain imaging, noninvasive brain stimulation and computational modeling. The outcome of this work will lead to a better understanding of the biological basis of human perceptual awareness in both normative and clinical populations. The educational activities supported by this award are intended to stimulate scientific interest and enthusiasm in neuroscience in student populations, and increase the use of computational neuroscience and state-of-the-art multimodal imaging tools in human neuroscience research. 

The research objective of this proposal is to tackle a central question in neuroscience: How does the brain give rise to perceptual awareness of sensory stimuli? To investigate this question, the research group will combine psychophysics, multi-modal brain imaging, and noninvasive brain stimulation in humans, facilitated by computational modeling, and use vision as the model system. Specifically, the following questions are addressed: 1) Do neural activities in frontal regions contribute to perceptual content when stimulus ambiguity must be resolved? 2) Do neural activities in frontal regions contribute to gating the access to awareness by a particular piece of visual information? The central hypothesis is that large-scale brain activity during conscious visual perception exhibits initial-state-dependent, robust, transient dynamics shaped by the interactions between frontal and visual cortices. The experimental approach features recording of brain activity at whole-brain and large-scale network levels using a combination of ultra-high-field (7 Tesla) functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), magnetoencephalography (MEG), and electrocorticography (ECoG) to leverage the high spatial or high temporal resolution of each modality, and to further manipulate brain activity using high-definition transcranial direct current stimulation (HD-tDCS). These studies will have a major impact for understanding how brain systems coordinate to generate perceptual awareness of environmental input.

por.por_cntn:
Despite the enormous progress in neuroscience over the past century, the neurobiological basis of our subjective awareness remains a mystery. Advances over the past decades have now enabled one major component of this question to be rigorously addressed by modern neuroscientific tools. That is, how does the brain give rise to perceptual awareness of sensory stimuli?

With the support of this NSF CAREER award, we addressed this key question by combining visual psychophysics, state-of-the-art multimodal human brain imaging, noninvasive brain stimulation and computational modeling. Specifically, in this project, we took vision as the model system and used two robust experimental paradigms, including bistable perception and threshold-level object recognition, to reveal how large-scale brain dynamics give rise to conscious visual perception. Our approach features recording of brain activity at whole-brain and large-scale network levels using a combination of ultra-high-field (7 Tesla) functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and magnetoencephalography (MEG) in healthy volunteers, and electrocorticography (ECoG) in neurosurgical patients, to leverage the high spatial or high temporal resolution of each modality, and to further manipulate brain activity using high-definition transcranial direct current stimulation (HD-tDCS). In additional, computational models of neural networks were constructed to better understand the mechanisms embedded within the observed neural activity.

These results have revealed important new insights into the neural mechanisms of visual perceptual awareness:

Using the bistable perception paradigm and noninvasive electrophysiology (E/MEG), we found that the content of conscious perception is encoded within the low-frequency (<5 Hz) aperiodic activity, so-called slow cortical potentials. By contrast, perceptual stability is promoted by increased oscillatory power in the high-frequency (alpha, ~10 Hz, and beta, ~20 Hz) ranges (Zhu et al., Sci Rep, 2022; Hardstone et al., eLife, 2022). Contrary to our initial hypothesis, we found that causal manipulation of the ventral prefrontal cortex using HD-tDCS did not have an effect on the behavioral dynamics of bistable perception.

Using the bistable perception paradigm and invasive electrophysiology (ECoG) in neurosurgical patients undergoing invasive monitoring for presurgical planning, we found that when the content of conscious perception is congruent with long-term prior knowledge learnt from lifelong experiences, there was dramatically increased top-down feedback brain activity. By contrast, when the participant experiences the perceptual outcome that is incongruent with prior knowledge, there was dramatically increased bottom-up feedforward brain activity. These empirical findings were captured elegantly by a computational model that incorporated both biophysical attractor-network and hierarchical predictive coding principles. These results (published in Hardstone et al., Nat. Commun. 2021) significantly advance our understanding of the role of prior knowledge and top-down feedback activity in shaping conscious perception.

Using the threshold-level object recognition paradigm and MEG to record brain activity, we uncovered two separate spontaneous processes, both measured in the pre-stimulus period, that predict conscious perception of a later presented image (Podvalny et al., Nat. Commun. 2019). A non-content-specific (NCS) process correlates with moment-to-moment pupil size fluctuations, suggesting that it is modulated by the subcortical arousal system. This NCS spontaneous process influences subjects’ conscious perception by shifting the detection criterion in the liberal direction, such that both hits and false alarms are more likely. By contrast, a content-specific (CS) process is unrelated to arousal and influences conscious perception by enhancing detection sensitivity, such that participants are better at distinguishing meaningful images from noise images. In addition, the discovery of doubly dissociable NCS and CS spontaneous processes reconciles previously competing frameworks about spontaneous activity that have postulated that it either serves content-specific functional roles or reflects generic arousal/behavioral state fluctuations. Our results show that both frameworks are correct and are reflected in different components of spontaneous activity that coexist. A follow-up study further revealed large-scale cortical activity changes correlated with moment-to-moment pupil size fluctuations (Podvalny et al., eLife 2021).

Finally, using the same threshold-level object recognition paradigm and 7T fMRI, we examined the spatial distribution of neural activity underlying conscious perception and the information content contained in such activity (Levinson et al., Nat. Commun. 2021). Contrary to previous suggestions, we found that whether the stimulus is consciously recognized or not, it activated and deactivated the same large-scale brain networks; however, only the consciously recognized stimulus content is decodable in these brain areas. Interestingly, subcortical regions exhibited heightened activation during conscious recognition but no content-specific information. Together, these results reveal content-specific cortical activity and non-content-specific subcortical activity that coordinate to generate conscious perception.

These studies significantly further our understanding of how brain systems coordinate to generate perceptual awareness of environmental input. In addition to the above research articles, this award has supported the development of several review articles (in Annu. Rev. Neurosci., Neuroimage, and Neuroscience of Consciousness). These basic science findings have also inspired new hypotheses about the biological basis of perceptual disorders such as hallucinations. The educational activities supported by this award has stimulated scientific interest and enthusiasm in neuroscience in diverse student populations.
